Query: What will you pay if my car is damaged?
Response: We’ll pay the cost of repairing or replacing your car up to its UK market value at the time of the claim.

Query: Who is covered to drive other cars?
Response: Your certificate of motor insurance will show who has cover to drive other cars. Only third-party injury or damage is covered.

Query: Am I covered if I leave my car unlocked or the keys in the car?
Response: No, we won’t pay a claim for theft or attempted theft if your car is left unlocked, with keys in the car, or with the engine running.

Query: What’s not included in my cover?
Response: Mechanical or electrical failure, wear and tear, damage to tyres caused by braking, and breakdowns are not covered.

Query: Does Churchill have approved repairers?
Response: Yes, Churchill customers have access to a national network of approved repairers.

Query: What is DriveSure?
Response: DriveSure is our telematics insurance product that captures driving data to understand your driving style and adjust your premium.

Query: What’s the difference between commuting and business use?
Response: Business use covers driving for business or employment purposes, while commuting covers driving to and from a permanent place of work.

Query: Can I use my car abroad?
Response: Cover depends on the policy type and destination. You may need a Green Card. Details are in ‘Where you can drive’ on page 31.

Query: Are my electric car’s charging cables covered?
Response: Home charger and charging cables are covered under ‘Section 2: Fire and theft’ or ‘Section 4: Accidental damage’.

Query: Is my electric car battery covered?
Response: Your electric car’s battery is covered if damaged due to an insured incident, whether it’s owned or leased.

Query: How do I make a claim?
Response: Call 0345 878 6261 for claims or 0800 328 9150 for windscreen claims if you have Essentials, Comprehensive or Comprehensive Plus cover.

Query: What details are needed to start a claim?
Response: Provide your personal details, policy number, car registration, and a description of the loss or damage. If in an accident, provide the other driver’s details.

Query: What should I do if I get communication from a court?
Response: Contact us immediately if you receive any court communication or legal threats. We’ll guide you on what to do.

Query: Do I need to avoid increasing the amount claimed?
Response: Do not admit liability or negotiate to settle any claim without our written permission to avoid increasing the claim amount.

Query: When do I need to pay the excess?
Response: You need to pay an excess for some claims, as specified in your car insurance details. No excess if not at fault and costs are recovered.

Query: What happens if my car is leased or bought on hire purchase?
Response: If the car can’t be repaired and it’s leased, claims are paid to the lease company. For hire purchase, claims go to the legal owner.

Query: How do repairs and replacements work?
Response: Repairs are carried out if financially sensible. Approved repairers provide a 5-year Guarantee. Repairs can be at a chosen repairer but not guaranteed by us.

Query: What is the 5-year guarantee for repairs?
Response: The 5-year Guarantee covers parts, materials, and workmanship by our approved repairer unless sold or leased ends.

Query: Can I choose my own repairer?
Response: Repairs can be at a repairer of your choice with our approval, but these repairs are not guaranteed by us.

Query: How are windscreen repairs handled?
Response: Glass may be replaced by a similar standard glass not made by your car’s manufacturer. Non-approved repairs have limited cover.

Query: Can parts from non-manufacturers be used for repairs?
Response: We may use parts not made by your car’s manufacturer but of similar standard, including recycled parts.

Query: What happens if my car can’t be driven after an accident?
Response: We cover reasonable costs to take your car to the nearest suitable repairer and arrange transport for you and your passengers.

Query: How is my car delivered after repairs?
Response: We cover reasonable delivery costs to return your car after repairs to the address on your car insurance details.

Query: What happens if my car is written off?
Response: If written off, we settle the claim, fulfilling our policy obligations. No premium refund if paid annually; instalment payments due under credit agreement.

Query: Is there a refund on my premium if my car is written off?
Response: No premium refund if your car is written off and you pay annually. Instalments must be paid if under a credit agreement.

Query: What does ‘Comprehensive with DriveSure’ cover?
Response: It provides the same cover as Comprehensive. All mentions of Comprehensive in the policy booklet also apply to Comprehensive with DriveSure.

Query: What’s included in the policy booklet?
Response: The policy booklet, car insurance details, and certificate(s) of motor insurance, and, if applicable, the Green Flag and DriveSure documents.

Query: What is an ‘approved windscreen supplier’?
Response: A repairer authorized to repair or replace your car’s windscreen.

Query: What is a ‘courtesy car’?
Response: A temporary small hatchback car provided by an approved repairer on our behalf.

Query: What is a ‘cyber event’?
Response: An unauthorized, malicious, or criminal act affecting electronic communications, data, or service availability.

Query: What is a ‘certificate of motor insurance’?
Response: A document proving you have the required insurance by law, showing who can drive the car and its permitted uses.

Query: What is a ‘convertible’?
Response: A car with a removable or retractable roof, also known as a cabriolet, roadster, soft-top, or hard-top.

Query: What is a ‘market value’?
Response: The cost to replace your car with one of similar make, model, age, mileage, and condition at the time of the accident or loss.

Query: What is a ‘main driver’?
Response: The person declared as the main user of the car in your car insurance details.

Query: What is a ‘period of insurance’?
Response: The length of time you have insurance cover under this policy, found on your certificate of motor insurance and car insurance details.

Query: What is a ‘policyholder’?
Response: The person named as the policyholder in your car insurance details.

Query: What are ‘removable electronic equipment’?
Response: Electronic equipment designed for in-car use but removable, excluding speed assessment detectors or personal portable equipment.

Query: What are the ‘territorial limits’?
Response: Great Britain, Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man.

Query: What does ‘written off’ mean?
Response: When your car is so badly damaged it’s no longer roadworthy or uneconomical to repair, based on its market value.
